1. Engage Objective: Introduce the challenge and inspire action. Teacher Role: •Act as the city leader and set the stage by presenting the tourism problem. •Share an engaging and motivating script to get students thinking about the challenge. Script Example: “Ministry team, our city has a rich culture and history, but tourism has been declining. Visitors want unique and engaging experiences, especially ones that involve advanced technology. Your task is to come up with an innovative attraction that blends our city's cultural heritage with high-tech solutions. We need something so amazing that it becomes a must-visit destination. I’m relying on your creativity and expertise!” Student Role: •Listen actively to the city leader’s speech and get excited about the challenge. •Start thinking about the cultural uniqueness of the city and how technology can be integrated. Strategy to Implement: •Hook: Begin with an impactful scenario where the city needs innovative ideas to boost tourism. •Use a motivational tone to create a sense of urgency and importance. Teacher Tip: Use visuals or a video clip showcasing iconic landmarks with a futuristic twist to spark students’ imagination.
2. Explore Objective: Encourage students to think broadly about potential solutions. Teacher Role: •Divide the students into groups, each representing a different branch of the Ministry (e.g., Culture, Technology, Tourism). •Assign roles within the groups (e.g., leader, note-taker, presenter). Activity: •Groups brainstorm ideas for a new tourist attraction that combines cultural heritage with advanced technology. •Each group discusses: • What makes the city unique in terms of cultural elements, landmarks, or history. • What kinds of experiences attract modern tourists (e.g., immersive, interactive). • What high-tech solutions could make tourism more engaging (e.g., VR, robotics, interactive exhibits). •Each group presents a brief list of ideas to share with the class. Student Role: •Actively participate in brainstorming sessions, contributing their knowledge of the city’s history and modern tourist trends. •Collaborate with team members to generate creative ideas for integrating technology into the city’s culture. Strategy to Implement: •Use brainstorming and mind mapping to guide students as they explore possible solutions. •Encourage creative thinking and make sure each group presents their findings. Teacher Tip: Use sticky notes or a digital tool to collect ideas from each group, allowing for quick review and feedback.

3. Explain
Objective: Narrow down ideas and focus on the concept of a high-tech museum. Teacher Role: •Guide students by asking probing questions to help refine their ideas. • “How can we make history come alive for tourists?” • “What if visitors could interact with our cultural landmarks instead of just looking at them?” • “How can technology transform traditional attractions?” •Facilitate a class discussion to clarify the vision of creating a high-tech museum that embodies both culture and technology. Activity: •After brainstorming, students share their group results with the rest of the class. •Engage in a class discussion to explore which ideas will work best, and refine these ideas into a cohesive museum concept. Student Role: •Share and explain the ideas generated in their groups. •Listen to others’ ideas and collaborate in refining them, while keeping the focus on creating an immersive, tech-driven museum. Strategy to Implement: •Use group sharing followed by a class discussion to refine ideas. •Encourage students to focus on blending high-tech solutions (e.g., AR/VR, robotics) with cultural heritage.
4. Elaborate Objective: Flesh out the concept of the high-tech museum by assigning specific roles. Teacher Role: •Assign different focus areas to each group (e.g., Theme Development, Tech Integration, Visitor Experience, Promotion). •Guide each group with questions to help them dive deeper into their assigned area: • Theme Development: What should the museum’s theme be? Local culture, global innovations, historical landmarks? • Tech Integration: How will technology be used to enhance the visitor experience (AR/VR, robotics, etc.)? • Visitor Experience: What kind of interactive, engaging activities should be included (hands-on exhibits, holograms, etc.)? • Promotion: How will the museum be marketed to attract tourists (social media, advertising, partnerships)? Activity: •Each group works on their assigned aspect of the museum’s concept. •After brainstorming, each group prepares a presentation of their aspect of the museum. Student Role:
•Collaborate within groups to develop ideas and come up with creative solutions. •Present their assigned section of the museum plan to the class. Strategy to Implement: •Encourage role-based collaboration where each group becomes an expert in a specific area of the project. •Use creative tools such as mind mapping, prototyping, or mockups to bring ideas to life. Teacher Tip: Circulate during the group work phase to ensure each group stays on task and offers guidance where needed.

Evaluate
Objective: Present the final museum plan and evaluate the feasibility of the project. Teacher Role: •Facilitate the final presentations by each group, ensuring they stay focused on their assigned aspect of the museum. •Provide feedback after each group presents, encouraging improvements and collaboration. •Ask reflective questions: • “How feasible is this museum in real life?” • “What makes your museum different from others?” Activity: •Each group presents their part of the high-tech museum concept. •The class collaborates to combine all aspects into a unified proposal. Student Role: •Present their section of the museum concept clearly and engagingly. •Listen to feedback from the class and the teacher to improve and finalize the museum concept. Strategy to Implement: •After each group presentation, allow for peer feedback. •Use a rubric to evaluate presentations based on creativity, feasibility, and teamwork. Teacher Tip: End with an inspiring conclusion, praising the students for their creativity and innovation, and emphasize the potential impact their museum concept could have on tourism.
Assessment Criteria: •Creativity: How unique and engaging is the proposed idea? (e.g., Does it stand out from other tourist attractions?) •Relevance: Does it effectively highlight the city’s culture and history? (e.g., How well does it represent local landmarks and heritage?) •Feasibility: Can the solution realistically be implemented in terms of technology and resources? (e.g., Is it practical?) •Collaboration: Did the group work effectively as a team? (e.g., Was the project completed in a timely and organized manner?)
